title: The most popular fact checks of May
subtitle: Hillary Clinton tops our monthly round-up with a Four-Pinocchio claim.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
1: Clinton’s claim that illegal immigrants pay more in taxes than some corporations

Clinton had claimed that undocumented workers pay more in taxes than some corporations. But she failed to consider that even if a company pays little or no income taxes, it pays plenty in other taxes, such as property taxes. In every case we checked, the companies paid more in taxes, and so Clinton earned Four Pinocchios.

2: Bush’s claim that Islamic State ‘didn’t exist when my brother was president’

This sweeping statement by the former Florida governor fell apart under scrutiny as the Islamic State was founded in 2006, when his brother was president, and al-Qaeda in Iraq was never “wiped out,” as he also claimed.

Warren made this claim based on a study by the Center for Responsible Lending, but the report was very sketchy, because it did not disclose that it was based on data for subprime loans. The underlying data source also showed different figures. Moreover, Warren incorrectly characterized the findings of the report. So she earned Four Pinocchios.

4: Setting the record straight on measuring fetal age and the ‘20-week abortion’

This was an informational article to explain a little-known difference between two methods of counting gestational age that contributed to inconsistent media coverage about a bill that proposes to ban abortions after “20 weeks.”

Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif earned two Pinocchios for making a claim about the size of Israel’s nuclear arsenal that far exceeded most mainstream estimates.
